Title: Evaluate $\int_0^\pi xf(\sin x)dx$
Content: Let $f(\sin x)$ be a given function of $\sin x$. How would I show that $\int_0^\pi xf(\sin x)dx=\frac{1}{2}\pi\int_0^\pi f(\sin x)dx$?
AcceptedAnswer:
If you make the substitution $w = \pi-x$ , so that $dw = -dx$ , you get \begin{align}
\int_0^\pi xf(\sin x)dx &= -\int_\pi^0 (\pi-w)f(\sin(\pi-w))dw \\
 &= \int_0^\pi (\pi-x)f(\sin(x))dx \\
 &= \pi\int_0^\pi f(\sin(x))dx - \int_0^\pi xf(\sin(x))dx
\end{align} which gives the result you want.
